There are 15 different holy books that Members can swear their oaths on. 

Swearing in is the process of making an oath - or a solemn affirmation - of allegiance to the Crown. Members of both the Commons and the Lords are required to swear in before they can take their seats. https://t.co/HD7bCCoPKm

The 2019-2021 parliamentary session ended on Thursday 29th April, with the prorogation ceremony. The new session will begin on Tuesday 11th May, with the Queen's Speech and State Opening. Here's a summary of what happened in the last parliamentary session: https://t.co/TrxjLej3Yf

The State Opening of Parliament takes place on 11th May. For today's archive post we have the Yeomen of the Guard.

Before the Sovereign's arrival at Parliament, the royal bodyguards ceremonially search the cellars of the Palace  for explosives. https://t.co/qkKbLuBXrp

Hidden away in the Palace of Westminster lies the 16th century Cloister Court, one of the most ancient and intricate parts of the sprawling building.

Read to find out more about the restoration of Parliament's historic Cloister Court: https://t.co/2WabxWiw2F

This week's Friday photo - 20m (65 ft) far above Central Lobby, there's wooden shed that teeters upon the golden dome. Housed within is a rusty winch system (that hasn't been used in decades) and a secret starlit skyscape. 

Read more: https://t.co/krZQhDcNXu https://t.co/bdNffvtBU2

The present chair was given by Australia and is made of black beanwood.

Today's photo from our archives is the Members‚Äô Lobby and Churchill arch.

Read the letter from the Speaker to MPs outlining a proposed voting system for today: https://t.co/War14CtFih https://t.co/EiwODEttdu

Proxy voters will declare at the Despatch Box that they are voting on behalf of another MP. 

If another Division is called immediately afterwards, there will be a 5 minute suspension to avoid the risk of double voting. https://t.co/W1f5nfVaR1

The process will take slightly longer than a standard division.

Voting will be broadcast with audio on Parliament TV. 

Parliament TV: https://t.co/9aRt5GUJv2 https://t.co/cSha3ZmSA1

MPs will file past the left side of the Table to vote aye, and the right side of the Table to vote No. 

At the Despatch Box the MP will pause, and state their name and how they are voting.

MPs will then file out of the Chamber and disperse. https://t.co/sickn3QntT

MPs in the Chamber will form a queue in the Chamber stretching back from the Table, 2 metres away from each other. 

The queue will file out of the Chamber along a pre-defined route. 

The Speaker will signal for MPs to begin moving forward. https://t.co/6PtcY5ki3C

Voting lobbies will not be used, to comply with social distancing guidance. 

When a division (vote) is called, tellers will position themselves either side at the back of the Speaker‚Äôs chair. 

Tellers are appointed to verify the count when there is a division. https://t.co/gOUhNhr1hg

Remote voting was agreed to on 21 April but this has now lapsed. 

Therefore, MPs will have to vote physically instead of remotely on voting procedures, if a division is called. https://t.co/Kc6dmbyEEp

The Ladies' Gallery created by Charles Barry had windows covered with heavy metal grilles, making it difficult to see or hear.  

The grilles became both a physical and metaphorical symbol of women's exclusion from Parliament, and later a target of suffragette agitation.

In 2005, he also became the first MP to disclose his HIV+ status. #LGBTHM2020 https://t.co/rkH13OUAaS

@visitparliament @UKLabour Ms Colquhoun was outed ‚Äì her sexuality made public against her will ‚Äì by a journalist when living with her partner, Barbara Todd.

@visitparliament The first openly lesbian MP was @UKLabour's Maureen Colquhoun, MP for Northampton North.

The NHS Funding Bill has passed its Third Reading without a division.

MPs have voted against New Clause 4 of the NHS Funding Bill by 293 votes to 162 votes. 

The New Clause related to the Health Secretary being required to give an annual report on whether the allotment of funds set out in the Bill is sufficient to meet performance targets. https://t.co/5oGCfGkPQv

MPs have voted against Amendment 3 to Clause 1 of the NHS Funding Bill by 298 votes to 161 votes.

The Amendment related to meeting the NHS England allotment for resource spending by using funds from NHS capital budgets. https://t.co/rXtmfJKQoI

MPs have voted against Amendment 2 to Clause 1 of the NHS Funding Bill by 300 votes to 163 votes. 

The Amendment related to the Health Secretary giving an annual report on the amount spent on mental health services and detailing plans to achieve parity. 

https://t.co/uP0ggBcUZ6 https://t.co/Q89nj2ekjB

MPs are voting on Amendment 2 to the NHS Funding Bill.
Because the Bill relates exclusively to England, only MPs for English constituencies can vote at this stage of the process.
Find out more about 'English Votes for English Laws'
https://t.co/S4eaYaP4n0

To celebrate this year's #LGBTHistoryMonth, we're delving into the history of LGBT+ representation and rights in the House of Commons. 

If you want more parliamentary LGBT+ history then join @visitparliament's themed tour through the Archives: https://t.co/IffrVXyzWL https://t.co/TwtSdnfsEe

The 2017-19 session lasted 349 sitting days.

The Commons scrutinised and held the Government to account, through asking in excess of 103,000 written questions and 307 Urgent Questions asked of Ministers. https://t.co/FLA9WE3Fnj

65 Public Bills were given Royal Assent, passing into law. 

14 of the bills were Private Members‚Äô Bills, giving individual MPs the opportunity to have a lasting impact on laws. 

Find out more about bills here: https://t.co/gYAkCME0fl https://t.co/nBQCumSRQc

Select Committees scrutinised the work of Government.

The 2017-19 session saw over 3,100 evidence sessions, questioning over 7,400 witnesses. This led to the publication of 757 reports.

Find out more about committees here: https://t.co/OniCnCKB4F https://t.co/o6rcnwOjtq

The 2017-19 parliamentary session was the longest in recent history.

The Sessional Return is now available, it is the authoritative source for statistics about the work of the Commons and its Committees. Find out more: https://t.co/eBGANEfBBr

The European Union (Withdrawal Agreement) Bill will now return to the House of Lords for consideration.

MPs have voted to disagree with Lords Amendment 5 to the European Union (Withdrawal Agreement) Bill by 349 votes to 246. This relates to clause 38 on the Sewel Convention. 

Read the list of the Lords Amendments here: https://t.co/hch3OAluqR

MPs have voted to disagree with Lords Amendment 4 to the European Union (Withdrawal Agreement) Bill by 342 votes to 254. This relates to Clause 37 on unaccompanied child refugees being allowed to join their families in the UK after Brexit.

Read more here: https://t.co/hch3OAluqR

MPs voted to disagree with Lords Amendment 3 to the European Union (Withdrawal Agreement) Bill by 350 votes to 247. This relates to powers of ministers to decide when to use or set aside judgements by the ECJ. 

Read a list of the Lords Amendments: https://t.co/hch3OAluqR

MPs voted to disagree with Lords Amendment 2 to the European Union (Withdrawal Agreement) Bill by 348 votes to 246. This would have made changes to Clause 26 on rights of UK courts to diverge from EU law after Brexit. 

Read a list of the Lords Amendments: https://t.co/hch3OAluqR

MPs have voted to disagree with Lords Amendment 1 to the European Union (Withdrawal Agreement) Bill by 338 votes to 252. This would have made changes to Clause 7 on rights related to residence. 

Read the list of the Lord's Amendments here: https://t.co/hch3OAluqR

MPs have voted against New Clause 55 of the European Union (Withdrawal Agreement) Bill, by 337 votes to 262.

This Clause relates to Northern Ireland's place in the UK internal market calling for unfettered access to the Great Britain market.

MPs have voted against New Clause 6 of the European Union (Withdrawal Agreement) Bill, by 347 votes to 251.

This would have ensured that MPs had a guaranteed vote with an amendable motion on the EU-UK Future Relationship and negotiating objectives.

MPs have voted against Amendment 4 to Clause 37 of the European Union (Withdrawal Agreement) Bill, by 348 votes to 252.

This would have protected the right for unaccompanied child refugees to be reunited with their family after Brexit.

MPs have voted against Amendment 10 to Clause 21 of the European Union (Withdrawal Agreement) Bill, by 340 votes to 262.

This would have applied restrictions on Ministers' delegated power to make regulations under the proposed new section 8C of the EU (Withdrawal) Act 2018.

MPs, led by the new Father of the House, Sir Peter Bottomley, go to the House of Lords where they receive a message from the Queen asking them to elect a Speaker.

The House will sit at 2.30pm to appoint a Speaker - this process happens after every general election.

As Sir Lindsay Hoyle was re-elected as an MP, a motion will be put to the House:

‚ÄòThat Sir Lindsay Hoyle do take the Chair of this House as Speaker‚Äô. 

Find out more:

The appointment of the Speaker will take place on 17 December. The Commons must choose its Speaker after every general election, and this is the first thing it does on the first day it meets after an election. 

The State Opening is on 19 December.
